preface.p: This document is for people who want to create a package for Fink. It complements the Packaging Manual, which is a more detailed and comprehensive document.

We'll guide you through the process of making a Fink package.
First we explain the general procedure. Then we show the creation of several Fink packages : maxwell and conglomerate

section.name: Learn
section.title: Learn the Basics
section.p: Please note: In this document we assume that fink is installed into /sw - the default location. If you see a codeblock similar to
it means that you have to type somecommand into Terminal.app or any other terminal on your Mac.
First you should learn a few basic concept about how to build Fink packages. We suggest you:

ul.li:
Have a look at
Using Fink: A Developer's How To (2MB pdf file) - slides from a presentation at the O'Reilly Mac OS X Conference.
Read and try to understand the example here.

Look at other, similar packages in your /sw/fink/dists/unstable/main/finkinfo/ directory or
in the online CVS repository and take one (or several) info file(s) as a starting point.
Search the Package Submission Tracker if somebody else already tried to package the same and the Package Request Tracker if there is a matching request. You might find valuable information there.
Maybe browse the Packaging Manual if you think you need more detailed information.

section.name: Make
section.title: Make your Package
section.p: Save your new info file (and patch file - if needed) into your /sw/fink/dists/local/main/finkinfo/ directory. The file should be named packagename.info (and packagename.patch) where packagename is the name of your package. If this directory doesn't exist you need to create it manually.
Check if fink found your package by typing:
If it doesn't show up in the list you might need to change your fink configuration file to include your local tree.
Maybe you also have to manually re-index your packages by typing:
If you need more information read the Packaging Manual or use one or more of different help sources. You should also subscribe to the fink-devel mailing list.

section.name: Validate
section.title: Validate your Package
section.p: During validation of your package you should set the verbose level of fink to the highest possible value. Check the section on the fink configuration file about how to change the verbose level.
Check if your package passes validation by running:
If the validation passes try to build your package with:

Watch the output of the build process carefully for errors or warnings. Especially make sure that everything is installed into the destination directory (which is located at /sw/src/root-packagename-%v-%r/sw) from where fink builds the binary package. Nothing should be installed directly into /sw.

If you use the --keep-build-dir or -k option to fink, it will keep the build directory. This is where fink expands the downloaded source and where the package gets built. This might help if you need to debug the build process. Type man fink for details.

You may also want to use the --keep-root-dir or -K option, it will keep the destination directory. This is where fink builds the installation tree for the package. Comparing build and destination directories may help you debugging the installation phase.
If the build succeeds check the content of the binary package with:
Check if all files that you think should be in the package are actually in the .deb file. Again: make sure that nothing is installed directly into /sw.
Now you can also validate the binary package by doing:
If all is well install the package with:
and test the functionality of your package.
If any of the above steps fail try to correct the errors and restart at the top with the fink validate step.

section.name: Submitt
section.title: Submit your Package
section.p:
If your package passes all the checks above you now can submit the info (and patch if necessary) file to the
Package Submission Tracker.

A package reviewer should now take a look at your package submission and add it to the Fink unstable tree if the package seems ready. If not you will be asked to bring the package into compliance with the policy.

ul.li: If feasible add multiple items one at a time to the same tracker item (e.g. info and patch files).
Add a note whether your package is intended for the 10.2-gcc3.3 tree, 10.3 tree, or both,
which section (graphics, sci, etc.) you feel it belongs in, and
that you have run the command fink validate on your info and deb files.

Set the Group field of the tracker item to Undergoing Validation when you create the new tracker. Also change it back to Undergoing Validation whenever you fixed problems package reviewers found in your submission.

section.name: Basics
section.title: Basics
section.p: First Maxwell. Lets open our editor and get started. We know the package name, its version and where to grab the source tar ball from. So we'll type this into our editor window:
section.codeblock: Package: maxwell Version: 0.5.1 Revision: 1 Source: mirror:sourceforge:%n/%n-%v.tar.gz
section.p: So we have the name and version which are easy to understand, but what of these other two fields? Revision is the "version" of the Fink package, Version, on the other hand is the upstream source version. Since this is the first time we have attempted to make a maxwell-0.5.1 package, it is revision 1.

The Source field is where fink will grab the source tarball from. Because Sourceforge has a system where packages are mirrored around the world, and since fink knows about it, we use mirror:sourceforge:. %n expands to the package name, maxwell, and %v expands to the package version, 0.5.1.
Now we can save this as maxwell.info in /sw/fink/dists/local/main/finkinfo/. That done, we can see how we are doing by using fink validate.
section.codeblock: finkdev% fink validate maxwell.info Validating package file maxwell.info... Error: Required field "Maintainer" missing. (maxwell.info)
section.p: Oops, looks like we missed a couple of fields. Lets add some more:
section.codeblock: Maintainer: John Doe <jdoe@example.com> HomePage: http://maxwell.sourceforge.net License: MIT
section.p: We add ourselves as the maintainer of the Fink maxwell package and add it's homepage, looking at the sourceforge project page, we see that it is MIT Licensed, so we add that too. Now lets try again:
section.codeblock: finkdev% fink validate maxwell.info Validating package file maxwell.info... Warning: Unknown license "MIT". (maxwell.info) Error: No MD5 checksum specified for "source". (maxwell.info) Error: No package description supplied. (maxwell.info)
section.p: Aaargh! We seem to be getting worse, not better, never mind, head off over to the Packaging Manual to see what is allowed for License, and we see that we can just change MIT to OSI-Approved, as the MIT license is, indeed, approved by the OSI. We can also grab a one line description of the package from the homepage. So we change those:
section.codeblock: License: OSI-Approved Description: Mac OS X S.M.A.R.T. Tool
section.p: But what to do about that warning about MD5 checksums? Well, why don't we just ask fink to fetch the source?
section.codeblock:
finkdev% fink fetch maxwell /usr/bin/sudo /sw/bin/fink fetch maxwell Reading package info... Updating package index... done. Information about 3377 packages read in 30 seconds. WARNING: No MD5 specified for Source of package maxwell-0.5.1-1 \ Maintainer: John Doe <jdoe@example.com> curl -f -L -O http://distfiles.opendarwin.org/maxwell-0.5.1.tar.gz % Total % Received % Xferd Average Speed Time Curr. Dload Upload Total Current Left Speed 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 --:--:-- 0:00:00 --:--:-- 0 curl: (22) The requested URL returned error: 404 ### execution of curl failed, exit code 22 Downloading the file "maxwell-0.5.1.tar.gz" failed.
(1) Give up (2) Retry the same mirror (3) Retry another mirror from your continent (4) Retry another mirror (5) Retry using next mirror set "sourceforge"
How do you want to proceed? [3] 5 curl -f -L -O http://west.dl.sourceforge.net/sourceforge/maxwell/maxwell-0.5.1.tar.gz % Total % Received % Xferd Average Speed Time Curr. Dload Upload Total Current Left Speed 100 7856 100 7856 0 0 19838 0 0:00:00 0:00:00 0:00:00 6511k
section.p: The tarball couldn't be downloaded from the Fink mirrors (distfiles) since your package is not added to the distribution yet. That's why you need to change to the next mirror set. More information about this problem is in the FAQ.
So we can now get the md5 by running md5sum /sw/src/maxwell-0.5.1.tar.gz, and add it to the .info file:
And now we find that fink validate passes, yippee!

section.name: build
section.title: Build
section.p: Now we can build the package, let's just try it:
section.codeblock: finkdev% fink build maxwell /usr/bin/sudo /sw/bin/fink build maxwell Reading package info... Updating package index... done. Information about 3498 packages read in 32 seconds. The following package will be built: maxwell gzip -dc /sw/src/maxwell-0.5.1.tar.gz | /sw/bin/tar -xvf - \ --no-same-owner --no-same-permissions maxwell-0.5.1/ maxwell-0.5.1/LICENSE maxwell-0.5.1/Makefile maxwell-0.5.1/maxwell.8 maxwell-0.5.1/maxwell.c maxwell-0.5.1/README ./configure --prefix=/sw Can't exec "./configure": No such file or directory at \ /sw/lib/perl5/Fink/Services.pm line 403.
section.p: Hmm, well that did not go all that well. Let's read the README (which you can find at /sw/src/maxwell-0.5.1-1/maxwell-0.5.1/README) and see what it says...
section.codeblock:
To build type 'make'.
To install in /usr/local type 'sudo make install', to install elsewhere, type 'sudo make install prefix=/elsewhere'
section.p: Ah hah, so we can't use the default CompileScript and InstallScript here, we need our own, that's easily resolved:
section.codeblock: CompileScript: make InstallScript: << #! /bin/sh -ev make install prefix=%i <<
section.p:
We need to use prefix=%i since fink builds the binary deb file from the files in %i. These files are later installed into %p (which is /sw by default) when you use fink install maxwell. For more details about %p and %i please consult the
Packaging Manual.

Normally the lines in the Script fields are passed line by line to the shell. But the #! /bin/sh -ev line makes fink run it as a separate script. The parameter -e means "die on error" and -v means "verbose".
So, let's validate the package again and try to rebuild it:
section.codeblock: finkdev% fink validate maxwell.info Validating package file maxwell.info... Package looks good! finkdev% fink build maxwell /usr/bin/sudo /sw/bin/fink build maxwell Reading package info... Updating package index... done. Information about 3498 packages read in 32 seconds. The following package will be built: maxwell gzip -dc /sw/src/maxwell-0.5.1.tar.gz | /sw/bin/tar -xvf - \ --no-same-owner --no-same-permissions maxwell-0.5.1/ maxwell-0.5.1/LICENSE maxwell-0.5.1/Makefile maxwell-0.5.1/maxwell.8 maxwell-0.5.1/maxwell.c maxwell-0.5.1/README make cc -L/sw/lib -c -o maxwell.o maxwell.c cc -I/sw/include -o maxwell -framework IOKit -framework CoreFoundation maxwell.o /bin/rm -rf /sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1 /bin/mkdir -p /sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1/sw /bin/mkdir -p /sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1/DEBIAN /var/tmp/tmp.1.A3sRc2 #! /bin/sh -ev make install prefix=/sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1/sw /usr/bin/install -d -m 755 /sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1/sw/doc/maxwell /usr/bin/install -m 644 LICENSE /sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1/sw/doc/maxwell/LICENSE /usr/bin/install -m 644 README /sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1/sw/doc/maxwell/README /usr/bin/install -d -m 755 /sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1/sw/bin /usr/bin/install -m 755 maxwell /sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1/sw/bin/maxwell /usr/bin/install -d -m 755 /sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1/sw/man/man8 /usr/bin/install -m 644 maxwell.8 /sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1/sw/man/man8/maxwell.8 /bin/rm -f /sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1/sw/info/dir \ /sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1/sw/info/dir.old \ /sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1/sw/share/info/dir \ /sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1/sw/share/info/dir.old Writing control file... Finding prebound objects... Writing dependencies... Writing package script postinst... dpkg-deb -b root-maxwell-0.5.1-1 /sw/fink/dists/local/main/binary-darwin-powerpc dpkg-deb: building package `maxwell' in \ `/sw/fink/dists/local/main/binary-darwin-powerpc/maxwell_0.5.1-1_darwin-powerpc.deb'.
section.p: Fink seems to have installed everything into the correct place: /sw/src/root-maxwell-0.5.1-1 from where the binary package maxwell_0.5.1-1_darwin-powerpc.deb was built.
Also note how fink automatically included some compiler flags to enable it to access other fink packages (e.g. -I/sw/include).
Let's have a look at what is in the binary package:
section.codeblock: finkdev% dpkg -c \ /sw/fink/dists/local/main/binary-darwin-powerpc/maxwell_0.5.1-1_darwin-powerpc.deb drwxr-xr-x root/admin 0 2004-07-15 09:40:38 ./ drwxr-xr-x root/admin 0 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/ drwxr-xr-x root/admin 0 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/bin/ -rwxr-xr-x root/admin 29508 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/bin/maxwell drwxr-xr-x root/admin 0 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/doc/ drwxr-xr-x root/admin 0 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/doc/maxwell/ -rw-r--r-- root/admin 1076 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/doc/maxwell/LICENSE -rw-r--r-- root/admin 1236 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/doc/maxwell/README drwxr-xr-x root/admin 0 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/man/ drwxr-xr-x root/admin 0 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/man/man8/ -rw-r--r-- root/admin 1759 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/man/man8/maxwell.8 drwxr-xr-x root/admin 0 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/var/ drwxr-xr-x root/admin 0 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/var/lib/ drwxr-xr-x root/admin 0 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/var/lib/fink/ drwxr-xr-x root/admin 0 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/var/lib/fink/prebound/ drwxr-xr-x root/admin 0 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/var/lib/fink/prebound/files/ -rw-r--r-- root/admin 16 2004-07-15 09:40:39 ./sw/var/lib/fink/prebound/files/maxwell.pblist
section.p: Seems ok, right? But we have to verify that it complies with the Fink packaging policy. So let's validate it with:
section.codeblock: finkdev% fink validate \ /sw/fink/dists/local/main/binary-darwin-powerpc/maxwell_0.5.1-1_darwin-powerpc.deb Validating .deb file \ /sw/fink/dists/local/main/binary-darwin-powerpc/maxwell_0.5.1-1_darwin-powerpc.deb... Warning: File installed into deprecated directory /sw/doc/ Offender is /sw/doc/ Warning: File installed into deprecated directory /sw/doc/ Offender is /sw/doc/maxwell/ Warning: File installed into deprecated directory /sw/doc/ Offender is /sw/doc/maxwell/LICENSE Warning: File installed into deprecated directory /sw/doc/ Offender is /sw/doc/maxwell/README Warning: File installed into deprecated directory /sw/man/ Offender is /sw/man/ Warning: File installed into deprecated directory /sw/man/ Offender is /sw/man/man8/ Warning: File installed into deprecated directory /sw/man/ Offender is /sw/man/man8/maxwell.8
section.p: Oops... something is wrong. Let's consult the Packaging Manual again. It tells us to install man pages into /sw/share/man and files such as README into /sw/share/doc/%n. If we look into the Makefile of maxwell we see that the mandir and datadir can be set:
One easy way to fix that is to change the InstallScript to
and rebuild the package with
(We used fink rebuild because fink build would not do anything since the package was already built successfully.)
Review the contents of your deb file (with dpkg -c) to see where the files got installed now. Then validate the deb file again with fink validate. If all is well you can install the new package with:
section.codeblock: finkdev% fink install maxwell /usr/bin/sudo /sw/bin/fink install maxwell Information about 3377 packages read in 30 seconds. The following package will be installed or updated: maxwell dpkg -i /sw/fink/dists/local/main/binary-darwin-powerpc/maxwell_0.5.1-1_darwin-powerpc.deb Selecting previously deselected package maxwell. (Reading database ... 56046 files and directories currently installed.) Unpacking maxwell (from .../maxwell_0.5.1-1_darwin-powerpc.deb) ... Setting up maxwell (0.5.1-1) ...
section.p: You can now run the software by typing

Congratulations, you just finished your first Fink package! Now have a look at the other example and try to package something yourself by following the
Packaging tutorial from the beginning.
We are looking forward to your contributions to Fink!

section.name: Basics
section.title: Basics
section.p: We will create the necessary info and patch files to port conglomerate to Fink. Here, we assume that you are on Panther, 10.3 Fink unstable tree.
We need to do some preliminaries for easy browse of all needed documents.

First, we need the tarball. How to retrieve its location? A quick search with google leads to this place. At the top of the page, there is a link to download. We click on it, and then we'll find a link to the tarball page on SourceForge:

ol.li: Download the tarball from its original location and put it on your desktop.
Expand it by double-clicking on it.
Double-click on the new conglomerate-0.7.14 folder on your Desktop, so that it shows in the Finder and choose the column view.

section.p: Next, we surely want to browse the home page later to retrieve some information.
Then, we'll have to look into the Packaging Manual.
Another document we need to browse later is the Porting Manual.
We need also a terminal to issue some commands. So open a window in Terminal.app and move to your Desktop, i.e. issue:
And presumably, nedit to make a patch file.

Finally, we'll create an info file for Fink. As we are lazy (a fundamental quality for a porter), we'll just use the info file we've created for Maxwell as a template for the conglomerate Fink info file:

ol.li: Drag and drop the maxwell.info file located in your fink local tree (/sw/fink/10.3/local/main/finkinfo/maxwell.info) to your Desktop.
Open it with any text editor (TextEdit is perfect for that purpose) and save it under a new name, namely conglomerate.info.

section.p: Now we have all in place, it's time to begin.
First, we change the info file for use with conglomerate. Remember we have in it:
section.codeblock: Package: maxwell Version: 0.5.1 Revision: 1 Source: mirror:sourceforge:%n/%n-%v.tar.gz Maintainer: John Doe <jdoe@example.com> HomePage: http://maxwell.sourceforge.net License: OSI-Approved Description: Mac OS X S.M.A.R.T. Tool Source-MD5: ce5c354b2fed4e237524ad0bc59997a3 CompileScript: make InstallScript: << #! /bin/sh -ev make install prefix=%i mandir=%i/share/man datadir=%i/share/doc/%n <<
section.p: At first glance, we need to change all fields but the Revision one, since it's the first time we make a Fink package for conglomerate.
We already know the package's name and version from the tarball's name. So we change them to:
To check the download location, return to the tarball's location within your browser and pause the mouse onto the tarball's name. You'll see in your browser's status bar at the time of this writing:
The first part and last part:
matches the mirror:sourceforge: of the Source field.
The middle part:
matches exactly the %n/%n-%v.tar.gz part of the Source field.
Hence, no need to change the Source field.
For the Maintainer field, put what you want in it.
To change the HomePage field, return to the conglomerate home page, copy what is in your browser's url field and paste it into the info file. It becomes:

While you're at this page, look at the footer, you'll see the license's name under which conglomerate is licensed. This GNUGPL. So open the Packaging Manual, and go to the Package licenses section to check if this is an authorized license. Yes, it is, though it is denoted as GPL in Fink nomenclature, so we'll put GPL in the License field:
For the Description field, we return to the conglomerate home page and pick something meaningful, for example:
section.codeblock: Description: Graphical editor for XML documents
section.p: Now, we'll add a detailed description, explained in the Packaging Manual just above the SplitOffs section. We browse again the conglomerate pages to find something useful, namely the intro page. From the screenshots, it appears, conglomerate is kind of wysiwyg editor for DocBook documents with source view and export features, so we'll put that in the DescDetail field:
section.codeblock: DescDetail: << Conglomerate aims to be a wyziwyg editor for XML/DocBook documents with source view and export capabilities. <<
section.p: Note: the special structure of this field (here-document syntax-based) is explained in the File Format section of the Packaging Manual.
Now, it's time to compute the MD5-sum, just issue md5sum conglomerate-0.7.14.tar.gz in Terminal.app and copy the numeric part of the result in the Source-MD5 field:
Now, we are done with the most obvious part, we just need to comment out the CompileScript and InstallScript fields (we don't remove them since it may happen we will need them later):

section.name: source-tree
section.title: A glance at the source tree
section.p: In the previous example, we've experienced that there can be some directives in the original build process not conforming the Fink packaging policy. Therefore, instead of doing numerous tries, we will inspect systematically the files which concurs to this process.

First, we'll observe some files with uppercase names, such as AUTHORS, COPYING, and so on. What to do with them? The Directories section of the Packaging manual teach us their install location. Then, in the Install Phase of the Reference section, we'll find a DocFiles field, which seems appropriate. So, we populate this field with all files with uppercase names found in the source tree:
section.codeblock: DocFiles: AUTHORS BUGS COPYING INSTALL NEWS TODO
section.p: Incidentally we'll see a debian folder. It may be worth have a look at it, especially the patches folder. There's a no_scrollkeeper-update.dpatch in it. We are not using it, but we will follow the instructions in scrollkeeper.info in Fink's 10.3 unstable tree, to know what to do.

First we are told to remove -scrollkeeper-update -a $(scrollkeeper-localstate-dir) line from an omf-install/Makefile.in. There is no such file, but there is an omf.make file. We open it and see the offending line in it, but in two places:
So we'll make a patch (here with nedit) to remove both lines:

ol.li: Open omf.make (TextEdit is just fine for it).

Remove both lines, so that they look like this:
install-data-hook-omf: ... done
uninstall-local-omf: ... -rmdir $(omf_dest_dir)

Open nedit, click Shell->Execute commands submenu, and type in it:
cd ~/Desktop; diff -Naur conglomerate-0.7.14/omf.make conglomerate-0.7.14/omf-patched.make
Tips: to get the ~, just type a space after it. And use the up arrow to retrieve the last shell command executed. It will output something like that:
--- conglomerate-0.7.14/omf.make Thu Jan 22 11:45:14 2004 +++ conglomerate-0.7.14/omf-patched.make Mon Jul 19 15:41:07 2004 @@ -42,7 +42,6 @@ for file in $(omfincfile); do \ $(INSTALL_DATA) $(srcdir)/$$file $(DESTDIR)$(docdir)/$$file; \ done - -scrollkeeper-update -p $(scrollkeeper_localstate_dir) -o $(DESTDIR)$(omf_dest_dir)
uninstall-local-omf: -for file in $(srcdir)/*.omf; do \ @@ -50,4 +49,3 @@ rm -f $(omf_dest_dir)/$$basefile; \ done -rmdir $(omf_dest_dir) - -scrollkeeper-update -p $(scrollkeeper_localstate_dir)

section.p: Now, we have to tell fink to take this patch into account, so we'll go to the Patches section of the Packaging Manual, observe that our patch follows the established rules, and insert the following line in the conglomerate.info file:
That was only the first part of scrollkeeper instructions. Now we should add a dependency on scrollkeeper.

section.name: build
section.title: Build
section.p: Now we can build the package, let's just try it:
